channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: German Factory Orders Dip as Sluggish International Demand Weighs
item.description: Factory orders fell 1% on month in June, but were up overall in the second quarter of this year, a sign of resilience in the economy despite the hit from U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: President Trump—and his critics—have described his tariffs as an earthquake that would transform the U.S. economy. So far, the impact has been mostly a series of tremors.
item.description: U.S. tariffs are higher than they have been in decades. Their effects have been mild.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Chinese Competition Has Led to Job Losses in Eurozone Manufacturing, ECB Says
item.description: The central bank said the threat of job losses was set to intensify as U.S. tariffs force Chinese businesses to look for customers elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: India’s Central Bank Stands Pat as Tariff Pressures Linger
item.description: Uncertainties surrounding U.S. trade policy continue to cast a shadow over the Indian economy’s outlook.
item.dc:creator: Kimberley Kao

item.title: Federal Reserve governor Adriana Kugler is set to leave the central bank on Friday, and President Trump is seriously considering tapping her successor to be the next Fed chair
item.description: The early departure of Biden appointee Adriana Kugler offers the president potential help on interest rates—and a new way to make life hard for Chair Jerome Powell.
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: It’s been a wild economic ride lately. Some WSJ reporters got together to chew over how things are looking—and what to expect next.
item.description: It’s been a wild economic ride lately. Our reporters got together to chew over how things are looking—and what to expect next.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Wolfe

item.title: Canada Trade Deficit Inches Up in June
item.description: Tariffs and uncertainty drag on exports, pushing shortfall to a record in the second quarter
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: The Swiss president is heading to the U.S. in a last-ditch effort to head off punishing tariffs that threaten to cripple key sectors of the country’s economy
item.description: The recent U.S. decision to impose a 39% levy stunned the Alpine nation and upended months of negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: President Trump ruled out tapping Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent as chairman of the Federal Reserve
item.description: The president said he is considering four Fed chair candidates, including Kevin Hassett and Kevin Warsh.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: EU Continues to Press for Tariff Exemption on Wine, Spirits as Part of U.S. Deal
item.description: French politicians have called for alcoholic beverages to be exempt from a baseline 15% tariff that will hit a majority of goods from the EU later this week as part of the trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: French Industry Gets Boost From Soaring Aviation Output
item.description: The rise in production was largely due to a nearly 27% increase in non-automobile transportation equipment.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: China’s Services Sector Activity Accelerates
item.description: A private gauge of China’s services sector showed activity expanded at the fastest pace in more than a year in July, as demand improved during the summer travel rush.

item.title: U.S. Employment Trends Weaken, Underlining Labor-Market Jitters
item.description: The Conference Board’s Employment Trends Index fell to 107.55 in July from an upwardly revised 108.19 in June, the research group said.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: EU Prepares to Pause U.S. Counter-Tariffs for 6 Months
item.description: The European Union is preparing to suspend a package of retaliatory tariffs it had intended to impose on goods from the U.S. had it failed to secure a trade deal with President Trump by Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: Turkish Inflation Keeps Edging Down as Central Bank Primes More Rate Cuts
item.description: The continued easing in the speed of price rises means the inflation rate has for three months straight trended lower than at any point since the end of 2021.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: BOE Expected to Lower Its Key Rate Thursday and Signal More of the Same
item.description: The Bank of England is expected to stick to its cautious rate-cut path at a time when inflation remains high even as there are clear signs of a cooling jobs market.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Anxious shoppers, concerned about inflation and their personal finances, are cutting their spending to focus on essentials
item.description: Generic brands and bulk buying are on the rise as shoppers find themselves in a summer of economic uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Khan

item.title: A chief White House economic adviser said that Trump wants allies placed in the Bureau of Labor Statistics after the agency published a dismal jobs report and the president fired its commissioner
item.description: Kevin Hassett said the president wants his own people at the agency to provide “more transparent and reliable” jobs data.
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: Job seekers are out in the cold this summer. Especially the ones who have been hunting for a while.
item.description: The number of people unemployed for at least 27 weeks has topped 1.8 million: ‘I’m considering myself semiretired at this point.’
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, discussed the outlook for the labor market, inflation and interest rates during an interview. Here is a transcript.
item.description: Williams discussed the outlook for the labor market, inflation and interest rates during an interview with Wall Street Journal reporter Nick Timiraos.

item.title: U.S. job growth slowed in July, a signal that pockets of weakness which had been marring the labor market are starting to take hold
item.description: The latest month’s report ​suggests that pockets of weakness in the labor market are starting to take hold. Revisions showed employers added a combined 258,000 fewer jobs in May and June than estimated.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Four charts show how the condo market is floundering
item.description: More condos are on the market, and units are taking longer to sell.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: Pending Home Sales Fell Unexpectedly in June
item.description: The number of homes going under contract in the U.S. unexpectedly declined in June, as high prices and mortgage rates persist.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Consumer-Confidence Survey Improved in July
item.description: The Conference Board’s consumer-confidence index climbed to 97.2, from 95.2 in June. But American consumers’ economic mood remained clouded by tariff and labor market concerns.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Canada Housing Market Braces for Extended Pricing Slump
item.description: Home buyers and builders in Canada are in retreat, adding to the woes of an economy struggling under the weight of President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Ireland’s Economy Contracts as U.S. Front-Running Cools
item.description: A surge in exports to the U.S. which led Ireland to far outstrip the growth rates of other rich economies waned in the three months through June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Individual home buyers are largely locked out of the residential housing market, leaving room for investors
item.description: High interest rates and prices are deterring individual buyers, leaving an opening for firms to snap up single-family properties.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Capital Account: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans
item.description: As global fertility rates drop, two economists make the case for humans.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Key Rate Again as Economy Slows
item.description: Friday marked the second-straight time the Bank of Russia cut its interest rate after it lowered borrowing costs in early June.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Retailers Get Summer Boost as Drinks Sales Soar
item.description: Retail sales were 0.9% higher on month in June, with alcoholic and nonalcoholic drinks among the products which saw higher sales.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.K. Consumers Are Feeling Gloomier Amid Foundering Economy, Rising Prices
item.description: U.K. consumer sentiment worsened as the country faces an unhappy combination of weak growth and still-high inflation.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Global Economies Show Resilience Despite Tariff Fears, Surveys Show
item.description: The U.S. economy and its peers in Europe and Asia continued to show resilience in the face of high levels of uncertainty about the future of trade and international relations, although export orders weakened.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Fewer U.S. Jobless Claims Were Filed Last Week
item.description: U.S. initial jobless claims declined last week, according to the Department of Labor, extending a stretch of evidence that layoffs have remained constrained.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: German Consumer Confidence Hit by Economic Uncertainty
item.description: Sentiment continued to worsen as growing economic uncertainty encouraged shoppers to save rather than spend, according to a monthly survey.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Home prices rose to a new high in June while the crucial spring sales season fizzled
item.description: The key spring-selling season failed to deliver, making a housing-market recovery unlikely this year.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Leading Economies Must Work Together to Fix Imbalances, or Face Instability, Says BOE’s Bailey
item.description: The U.S., China and other leading economies should work together to agree on a set of national policies that will help narrow the large imbalances that now threaten the global trade system, the Bank of England governor said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon
